question: If a drug is active against the pre-erythrocytic stage of the malarial parasite it will be useful as a:
exp: If a drug is active against the pre-erythrocytic stage of the malarial parasite it will be useful as a Causal prophylactic. Stage killed Clinical Use Pre-erythrocytic Causal Prophylaxis Erythrocytic Clinical cure Suppressive Prophylaxis Exo-erythrocytic Radical cure Gametocytic Prevention of transmission

question: Which of the following antimalarial drug is a slow acting erythrocytic schizonticidal drug for malaria?
exp: Erythrocytic schizonticides may be fast acting or slow acting: Fast acting M - Mefloquine A - Atovaquone C - Chloroquine (and amodiaquine and piperaquine) H - Halofantrine (and lumefant rine) A - Aemisinins R - Res-Q (Quinine) - Slow acting: Proguanil Pyrimethamine Sulfonamides T Tetracyclines Clindamycin

question: All of the following are WHO recommended Aemisinin-based combination therapy except?
exp: Aemisinin are combined with several antimalarial drugs in ACT but these are not combined with Chloroquine or Quinine. COMBINATION THERAPY: (ACT) Aemisinin + Long acting drug DOC for Chloroquine resisitance Combinations are: (WHO RECOMMENDED) AEMETHER + LUMEFANTRINE- DOC in Noh Eastern States in INDIA AESUNATE + SULFADOXINE - PYRIMETHAMINE - DOC for all other states in INDIA AESUNATE + MEFLOQUINE AESUNATE + AMODIAQUINE DIHYDROAEMISININ + PIPERAQUINE

question: A patient is diagnosed with chloroquine resistant falciparum malaria. His treating physician advises nurse to administer quinine by IV infusion. The preferred IV fluid for quinine infusion is:
exp: - The nurse will give quinine infusion through 5% dextrose. - Hypoglycaemia is the most impoant side effect which can be prevented by infusing quinine in 5% dextrose. Note: Adverse effects of quinine infusion: Hypoglycemia is also common, mostly in the treatment of severe malaria, and can be life threatening if not treated promptly with intravenous glucose. Hypotension is rarer but also serious and most often is associated with excessively rapid intravenous infusions of quinine or Quinidine. Quinine diluted preferably in 5% (w/v) glucose solution to counteract hypoglycemia. In the absence of glucose, physiological saline may be used. This method of administration minimizes the danger of severe hypotension and subsequent respiratory collapse. Don't give quinine as bolus. OTHER ADVERSE EFFECTS: 'Cinchonism' Syndrome Large single dose or higher therapeutic doses taken for a few days. Consists of ringing in ears, nausea, vomiting (due to both gastric irritation and CTZ stimulation), headache, mental confusion, veigo, difficulty in hearing. Visual defects (due to direct neurotoxicity as well as constriction of retinal and auditory vessels). Diarrhoea, flushing and marked perspiration. Completely STOPS once the drug is stopped. - Seldomly cause hemolyisis and idiosyncratic reactions.

question: Regarding dihydroaemisinin pharmacokinetics, all are true except:-
exp: Dihydroaemisinin * It has potent schizontocidal action.* These drugs are lethal to early malarial gametes but not mature ones.* They do not kill vivax hypnozoites* The duration of action is sho and recrudescence rate is high.* Dose adjustment is not required in hepatic or renal failure.* Oral bioavailability is around 30%* Auto induction of metabolism.
opa: Dose adjustment is not required in hepatic or renal failure

question: Bull's eye maculopathy is an adverse effect caused by
exp: Bull's eye maculopathy It is a rare dystrophy, also known asbenign concentric annular macular dystrophy (BCAMD). It causes a daboard, or ring-shaped, pattern of damage around the macula. It can be caused bychloroquineorhydroxychloroquine Side effects of antimalarial drugs Chloroquine (4-aminoquinoline) - Bull's eye maculopathy, confusion, psychosis, agranulocytosis. Primaquine (8-aminoquinoline ) - hemolytic anemia in G6. PD deficiency, leukopenia, agranulocytosis, leukocytosis, cardiac arrhythmias. Quinine - Cinchonism (constellation of symptoms: tinnitus, headache, nausea, dizziness, flushing, visual disturbances. Tafenoquine (8-aminoquinoline) - Hemolysis in G-6. PD Def Pt

question: All of the following drugs can be used for the management of malaria due to chloroquine resistant vivax except:-
exp: Fluroquinolones are not used for malaria DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria is ACT. ACT of choice all over India (except noh-east) is aesunate + sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine. ACT of choice for noh east states is aemether + lumefantrine. Other ACT approved by WHO are: Aesunate + amodiaquine Aesunate + mefloquine Dihydroaemisinin + Piperaquine Quinine with doxycycline (or clindamycin) is alternative drug for chloroquine resistant malaria

question: Which of the following antimalarial agents is most commonly associated with acute hemolytic reaction in patients with glucose-6- phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency?
exp: -Primaquine can cause hemolytic anemia in patients with even mild deficiency of G-6-PDdue to its oxidative propeies. - Symtoms include passage of dark coloured urine which indicate hemolysis and the drug must be stoppped. - Quinine, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can also cause hemolysis in G-6-PD deficient patients but the frequency is less than that of primaquine.

question: The fastest acting schizontocidal drug among the following is:
exp: Aemisinin derivatives like dihydroaemisinin, aeether and aemether etc. are fastest acting antimalarial drugs.

question: Loading dose is given for which of the following drug
exp: Chloroquine is a drug having maximum Volume of Distribution (Vd >1300 L). This means it is mostly distributed in the tissues whereas the main site of its pharmacological action is RBCs. Therefore, it is given as a loading dose to attain steady state plasma concentration quickly. Chloroquine is a synthetic 4-aminoquinoline that has been the mainstay of antimalarial therapy, is the drug of choice in the treatment of erythrocytic P. falciparum malaria, except in resistant strains.

question: Pyronaridine is an:-
exp: Pyronaridine is an anti-malarial agent related to amodiaquine. It is highly effective against chloroquine resistant falciparum malaria. Currently it is being evaluated in combination with aesunate.

question: Drug of choice for cerebral malaria is:-
exp: Drug of choice for cerebral malaria is parenteral aemisinins beacuse these are faster acting. more effective, better tolerated and more conveniently administered. Therefore aesunale (i. v./i. m.) or aemether ( i. m.) or aeether (i. m.) are now preferred over quinine for severe malaria. TREATMENT AND PROPHYLAXIS OF MALARIA (NATIONAL GUIDELINES ACCORDING TO NBVDCP) Treatment of Uncomplicated malaria Parasite Males and Non-pregnant females Pregnancy (1st trimester) Pregnancy (2nd and 3rd trimester) P. vivax(orP. ovale) Chloroquine + Primaquine Chloroquine Chloroquine P. falciparum(orP. malariale) ACT + Primaquine Quinine ACT Mixed ACT + Primaquine Quinine ACT Treatment of severe/complicated malaria P. falciparum Aesunate followed by oral ACT Aesunate followed by oral ACT Aesunate followed by oral ACT

question: What is DOC of Severe Complicated Falciparum Malaria is?
exp: AEMESININS: Aemisinin and its three major semisynthetic derivatives in clinical use Dihydroaemisinin, Aemether and Aesunate are potent and Fast-acting Antimalarials. They are optimized for the treatment of Severe P. falciparum malaria and are also effective against the asexual erythrocytic stages of P. vivax. AESUNATE - All patients with Severe Falciparum Malaria should be treated with I/V or I/M Aesunate (atleast 24 hours). The semisynthetic aemisinins have been formulated for Oral (Dihydroaemisinin, Aesunate, and Aemether); Intramuscular (Aesunate and Aemether); Intravenous (Aesunate); and Rectal (Aesunate) routes. AEMETHER - is used only if Parenteral Aesunate is not available PROPEIES: Fastest acting Antimalarial drug Effective against MDR parasites Sho acting C/I in 1st Trimester

question: Which of the following is used for single dose radical cure of Plasmodium vivax malaria?
exp: TAFEn. OQUINE: Single dose for radical cure of P. VIVAX malaria. Administered orally and single dose is sufficient due to long half life (2-3 weeks). Cause hemolysis in G6. PD deficiency patients. ELAGOLIX SODIUM: Gn. RH antagonist Given orally Approved for pain associated with endometriosis Sho acting IBALIZUMAB: Monoclonal antibody against CD4 receptor Inhibit fusion of HIV with CD4 receptor on host cells Used in HIV PATISIRAN: Approved for polyneuropathy with hereditary transthyretin mediated amyloidosis. It is small inhibitory RNA
